text: From tap. Dark amber reddish color with off white head. Aroma is malty and hoppy, caramel, piney citrusy fruity, grapefruit, grassy. Sweet and bitter taste like aroma. Medium oily body with soft carbonation.

Poured from a 22 ounce bomber. Aroma is filled with American hops, citrusy, pine, tropical fruits, caramel, toffee, sweet malts. The flavor is caramel, soft citrus hop character, toffee, hint of coffee in the finish, yeast esters, minerally. Very good, not to the Irish style, but tasty none the less.
Bottle share thanks to the dex the cat. Pours red, smooth taste, light, malty, not that hoppy for a three floyds beer. Goes down pretty easy.
Pours a reddish orange color with tan head. Sweet malty light floral hop nose. Sweet, malty, mild hop character.
Bottle share thanks to SexterCat. A toffee sweetness up front. Low but noticeable hop bitterness. Kinda red. I guess its good for a red. Just kinda red.

22oz. bottle. Lightly fruity and sweet aroma, some caramel and fresh citrus with notes of orange, pine, toasted biscuit and faint spruce. Cloudy medium-dark red in color with a rocky, lasting, off-white head and plenty of lacing to match. Flavor profile is very nicely balanced, with plenty of sweet, toasty, bready, nutty, amber malts, more caramel here as well, along with a tinge of red grape and tropical fruitiness, apple, faint pine, citric hop and a light-moderate level of bitterness arriving late. Lingering grassy, herbal tone on the finish. Smoothly but generously effervescent on the palate lending a smooth, creamy feel, body is medium. Oddly, carrot cake seems to be coming to mind here late into the bottle. Not really a problem because I love carrot cake. Really good stuff, overall.

Keg at Mikkeller & Friends post-CBC one night in 2013. Pours clear amber with a foamy, off-white head. Good beer with a character predominantly composed of pine, caramel and bready malts. Medium bodied with fine to average carbonation. Bready malt finish with mellow piney hops and toasty sugars. If you like malts, this is where its at.

A: Amber Hue, Passes Some Light, White Head Ring, Some Lacing

S: Floral, Deep Bready Malts, Mild Caramel

T: Floral, Bread, Mild Caramel, Mild Resin

M: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Malty, Hoppy

Overall, a great well blended malty. hoppy red ale...almost seems boozy but it is from the combination of the malts and hops.

Draught @ Mikkeller & Friends. Pours near clear amber with a small frothy beige head. Aroma is grapefruit, peach, pine, toffee, nut, citrus, deep resin and a woody note. Taste is light+ sweet and bitter. Body is medium, texture is smooth, carbonation is soft. Finishes balanced and hoppy. Malt- and underplayed hop-driven with great drinkabilty.

On tap at Mikkeller & Friends, july 16th 2013. Deep red with a white head. Aroma is heavily hopped, mango and pineapple, with biscuit and caramel, light yeast notes, good malty body with a very nice hop character of tropical fruits together with chocolate and grass. Nice citrusy ending, and a pleasant bitterness. A really nice beer by all accounts, though as hoppy as it is I find it an irish styled red ale by name only, more like a modern american style amber I think.

Fad: Rødrav farvet klar med et fint skumhoved. God duft af citrus humle og malt med malten som den dominerende part. dejlig frisk smag hvor malten på intet tidspunkt bliver for dominerende. I det hele taget en møg god øl.
Den här ölen blev jag aldrig riktigt klok på, smaken var märklig, fruktig och spretig dessutom var kroppen liten.
Brun i kroppen. En hel del frukt. Beskan lägger sig rätt snabbt. Fint balanserad.

Tap @ Mikkeller and Friends, Cph. Pours deep, hazy red with a small, creamy, beige head. Aroma has sweet malts, caramel, brewing cereal, baking yeast, red apples. Medium carbonation, fine creamy mouthfeel with some creaminess to it. Flavour has creamy caramel, soft butterscotch, piney and citrussy hops. Good bitterness. Very nice beer.
På mikkeller & friends. Maltig och pigg. Känns färsk och fräsch. Lite mer humle än jag är van med för IRA-stilen. Gillar skarpt. Lite för kall men har inget tålamod.

Very good. Doesn't really taste like a red. Very hoppy, fresh tasting with that 3F citrus kick to it. Enjoyable. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
At brew pub. Pours Deep amber white white head. Pine and citrus hops in the nose. A lot of malt in the taste, expecting some more hops. Nice

On tap at Mikkeller and Friends. Pours amber with a creamy off white head. The aroma is toasted malty and berries with fruity hoppy notes. The flavor is bread, malty and fruity. Bready and fruity finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap. Hazy amberbody with an average off-white head. Aroma of caramel and fruit notes. Sweet flavor that endsup more dry and slightly bitter. Medium bodied watery to oily texture and soft carb. A nice ale but not an exceptional one.

Tap at Mikkeller & Friends. Pours copper amber with a neat, short white head. Aroma is piney, spicy hops, bready malts and a light yeast leather character. Taste is smooth, crisp malts with a slight hop spice, a little dry and nice bitterness. Great drop.

Draft @ Mikkeller & Friends, Copenhagen. Pours a dark amber color with a small longlasting off-white head. Has a fruity malty spicy caramel hoppy aroma. Fruity malty spicy hoppy flavor with hints of caramel. Has a fruity malty hoppy spicy caramel finish.

Big caramel flavor and a mild malt character. Hopped to perfection. They got this one right!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draught @ Mikkeller & Friends. Pours hazy reddish brown with a creamy offwhite head that slowly dissipates while leaving a small trace on the glass. Smell is malty and hoppy with caramel, sweet dark bread, biscuits, pine needles, resinous wood, lemon zest and grass. Taste is sweet and bitter with sweet dark bread, biscuits, caramel, orange peal, pine needles, grapefruit rinds, resinous wood and subtle hints of alcohol. Motuhfeel is round, soft, tiny dry, tiny astringent and light to medium bodied. Finish is tiny sweet and bitter with sweet dark bread, caramel, biscuits, resinous wood, pine needles and grapefruit rinds.
22oz bottle from the pub. Pours a copper red with small white head. Caramel and toffee aroma. Bready malt taste.

bottle.  lovely fresh beer aroma.   some nice citrus with malt background.  perfect appearance.  tastes like it has massive backbone but at 5.5 its all flavour.  really nice job and went well with a hot sausage.
On tap at Mikkeller & Friends. Hazy copper brown. Toffee and citrus nose. Well-balanced, good toffee, but sufficiently bitter. Nice.

Tap. Hazy copper with a large creamy off white head. Caramel, toffee, wort, fruity hops. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation. Soft and smooth malty brew.

22 ounce bottle into pint glass, Spring 2013 bottling.  Pours lightly hazy reddish orange color with a 2 finger fairly dense light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers.  Spotty foamy lacing clings on the glass.  Aromas of caramel, raisin, apple, toast, toffee, biscuit, brown sugar, grapefruit, orange zest, floral, grass, slight pine, and light yeast earthiness.  Fantastic aromas with all around great balance and complexity of malt and yeast ester notes; with moderate hop presence and good strength.  Taste of caramel, apple, golden raisin, grapefruit, orange zest, toast, toffee, floral, grass, light pine, biscuit, and floral earthiness.  Fair amount of pine bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of caramel, light fruits, citrus, floral, grass, toast, toffee, light pine, and floral earthiness on the finish for a good bit.  Fantastic balance and complexity of malt, hop, and yeast ester flavors; with zero cloying flavors after the finish.  Medium carbonation and body; with a creamy, fairly crisp, and slightly sticky mouthfeel that is very nice.  Alcohol is very well hidden with hardly any warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is a fantastic Irish Red style!  All around great complexity and balance of malt, hop, and ester flavors; and extremely smooth to drink.  A highly enjoyable offering.

From tap at Mikkeller & Friends. Pours hazy orange to brown with a small off white head. Crisp hoppy. Smooth fruity. Toasted malty and grapefruity. Bitter, smooth fruity and lingering toasted malty and crisp hoppy finish,

Draught at Mikkeller & Friends
Hazy orange-red coloured with a medium sized off-white head.
Sweet and fruity aroma of caramel, hops, pine needles and cardamom.
Fruity flavour of hops, pine needles, peaches and grapefruits.
Dry hoppy finish.
Draught at Mikkeler & Friends. Color is red, nice aroma. Really malty taste but nice hops. Drinks very easily. Not exceptional, just really good.
Excellent aroma, fantastic appearance, very smooth finish.  Best Irish ale I have ever had!
Appearance clear amber with a slight white head aroma of strawberries with overtones of malt taste of fruit and malt smooth and  long on the palate
From a 22 oz bottle shared at home.  Pours a reddish gold with an off white head.  Fruity hop aroma.  Mellow hop backbone with some nice hop character.  Smooth as a babys bottom.

22oz bottle.  pours a clear amber under a large, whipped, beige head.  sweet, malty, worty, maris otter, cereal malty goodness with a distinct floral hop.  just enough floral/citrus hops to balance the residually sweet, worty tasting, toasty caramel malt flavor.   is this beer for real?  it tastes like a bowl of oatmeal covered in rich honey, brown sugar and syrup with a big, fat, handful of aroma hops and a fresh dry hopping session.  not very traditional, but when you make something this good, i suppose you can call it whatever you want.

Keg @ Mikkeller & Friends. The pours deep amber with a small head. The nose is red fruits, toasty malt, brown bread. A bit of nut and caramel. The taste is more red fruits, strawberry jam. Smooth, rich toffee and nut. Some glazed donut sweetness. Medium body, smooth and easy to drink. A pleasant malty brew. Solid.

Tap @ Mikkeller, Stefansgade. Hazy dark amber with a big and lasting off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and fruity. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 030513
Tap at Mikkeller & friends. Golden-amber colour with small off-white head.  Malt and hops aroma. Malt taste, with some caramel and hops. Slightly bitter.

On tap at Mikkeller & Friends, pours a deep dark orange with a small beige head. Aroma of dry bready malts, super dry caramel malts, and some earthy hops. Flavour of dry bready caramel malts, a touch of sweetness, and a hoppy finish. Very creamy palate, with a bready character. Solid Irish ale, if this can be classed as such.
(Short review due to the massive amounts of beer I drank during the CBC13.)  Tap at Mikkeller and friends. Very nice and drinkable!

Tap @ Mikkeller Bar, Stefansgade. Hazy dark amber with small off-white head. Aroma is malt, fruit, caramel and toasted. Flavour is malt, fruit, caramel, toasted, hops, little sweet, little grass and a little bitter.

On tap at Mikkeller & Friends.

A bit hazy dark reddish with a small head. This one was a nicely drinkable beer. Fruit, caramel, malt, bread and some light notes of grass.
Tap @ Mikkeller bar, Stefansgade. Nice head with good duration.  Color is amber. Aroma and taste are caramel,  fruits, malt, nuts and hops.

Draught at Mikkeller & Friends. Clear amber/copper beer with a small offwhite head. Sourish fruity aroma, caramel, hay, metal notes, grapes, citrus, some hay. Fruity hop flavor, caramel, floral notes, berries, raisins, grassy notes.

On tap. Pours light cloudy reddish with no head. Aroma of caramel malt, butterscotch, bread, citrus and pine. Taste is very British style malt bitter with sweet backbone. Abrupt finish. Light body, creamy with soft carbonation.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a medium brown color. Nose is caramel, toffee, resin. Taste is nutty, with caranel, apples, dried fruit and resin. Quite good.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours copper red with low white head
Aromas of smoked malts, pine, bready red malts
Nice sweetness but bit too much red maltyness making it nothing out of the ordinary

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours an nice red amber with an off white head and aroma of citrus, hops, and pineapple. Taste is sweet and well balanced, of caramel, hops, pine, toasty malt, and citrus with a long finish. Very drinkable, tasty brew, another great one from 3F

For my 700th has to be a 3Fs. Pours a reddish orange color with a nice frothy head. Nose is citrus especially pineapple and hoppy, rather delightful . Taste is sweet malt and caramel with some nice even bitterness. Finishes with the same flavors and lingers. Quaff Score 8 / 10

Bottle thanks to Jstax. Pours a rusty red with a finger of eggshell foam that coats the glass. On the nose its light and toasty. Grainy with a touch of caramel sweetness, lemon balm and sesame seeds. The palate is even more complex yet subtle. Nice toasted grapenut backbone thats round on the bottom end with a caramel roast and heightened on the front with citrus, lemongrass, oyster crackers and hay. Nice beer, usually not into red ales but Three Floyds is one of those breweries where Im willing to try anything they make.

Clear orange amber. Large frothy off-white head, lasting, sticky lace. Aroma is very bright, sweet, citrus, grapefruit, pineapple, some toffee, but mostly hops for me. Medium body - initially somewhat watery sweet and then sort of filling out, semi bitter finish, a little dryness. Restrained by FFF standards, but nicely balanced and well put-together.

Strong hop aroma.   Citrus and grapefruit.  Extremely large cream colored head.  amber.
initial sip is very light, with a bitter finish.  a little citrus, grapefruit taste.  Hard to really pick anything else out. Very very light. starts out almost watery, and then slowly gets heavier into a slight bitter finish.  fairly smooth.  Enjoyable.

Poured a hazy red with a finger and a half sized tan head.  I got aromas of grape, caramel, tootsie roll, and bread.  Taste was bland with the maltiness, but there was a noticable hop bite.  While not real big of a beer, the mouthfeel was thick and sticky.  A great example of a boring style.

22oz bottle shared with deliverydriver. Pours a a very hazy orange/amber with a finger and a half of creamy head that leaves decent lacing. Nose is hoppy, sweet and yeasty with with a strong malt presence. Hints of Dark fruits, mainly plum. Mouth is very malty with a slight hop bite. Once again, the plum comes through on the mouth. I had this beer in tap once before. I enjoyed it much more this time around.

Pour is amber/red with a two-finger-wide bubbly off-white head. Aroma is of bready malts, caramel, citrus, and fruity yeast. Flavor is not as complex as the aroma and much more hop forward. Citrus, light fruits, caramel throughout the body with a hoppy dry finish. Medium to high carbonation. Medium bodied.

From the April 2013 3R6P beer tasting. +++ Sampled from a 22 oz brown bottle this beer poured an orange-caramel color with a small foamy beige head that faded quickly and left no lacing. The aroma was dry, tart, faintly nutty and had a bit of dark fruits. The flavor was dryish caramel, bread, nut, dark fruits and turned a bit sour. Medium length dryish finish of caramel and dark fruits. Medium body. Eh.
Caramel and pineapple. Sums up the beer for me. Although I am nto a big fan of Irish beers. The bottle was also old, does not age well.

Bottle shared by John. Pours reddish brown with a modest beige head and a sweet and smoky aroma. There is a very well-balanced smoked malt flavor with some toffee and a mildly raspy finish. A very tasty red ale.
Bottle shared by john. Pours amber with white head. Aroma is slightly hoppy. Taste is malt with a nice hop balance

Bottle at my parents with my dad. Pour is deep, clear amber with a fluffy cream head an great lacing. Big hoppy aroma - resiny, light wet-dog, caramelly, biscuit, grassy, and straw. Taste is bready, caramelly, grassy, resinous, somewhat earthy, and straw with a nice hop bite on the finish. Medium body with high carbonation. Nice red ale.

Pours a clear golden color with just the slightest copper hue. The white head attenuates very quickly to a thin cap and, then, to nothing but a few bubbles.  Very light notes of Amarillo hops in the nearly absent bouquet. The mouthfeel is very pleasant with a thin, oily, moistness that would make nearly anything taste better. Clean Amarillo comes through with a little more grain depth than Gumballhead or Pride and Joy. There is a discernible flavor of peat in this beer that seems to define its overall character. Not a bad effort. Not stellar either.
Citrus hop aroma leaning towards a typical IPA. Nice balance between the red ale and an IPA, powerful hop wise without overpowering the red ale base.

Pretty hoppy for an Irish red but I definitely enjoyed it... Poured into a pint glass with a minimal head... Aroma was very good.  Poured an Ambery color.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22oz bomber poured into an imperial pint glass. Pours a copper color with a reddish hue. Initially a 3-finger head that disappated into a half-finger head that retains quite well. Lots of lacing. Aroma of pineapple, citrus, hops and malts. Taste is very fresh and crisp. Malts and citrus up front with the pineapple, toffee and hop bitterness coming in quite well behind it. Lingering malt and hop finish. Full body, but not overwhelming. Texture is creamy and sticky. Average carbonation. Another winner from Three Floyds!

Bomber to snifter (from notes).  Looks good; a deep red with off-white head.  Smells and tastes solid; malty with a bit of hops and bitterness.  Good on the palate with a nice, dry finish.  A good example of the style.

Pours a dark copper with thin lacing atop. Aroma is strong with hops. Almost so overpowering that a long sniff takes you straight to the battlefield in Ireland long ago. If the Warriors had drank this before battle they would have been assured a victory. Taste is very happy and refreshing with floral and fresh grassy notes. Palate is clean and bitter. A fantastic brew that may be a bit overlooked by many.

There s a lot of different tastes to this brew; I sorted out finding a taste of chocolate Oreos as being being the dominate flavor. generous amount of hops, as always by 3f. Nothing amazing, but definitely worth trying. low alc.% but makes up with loads of hops and other goodies.

Disclaimer - had this cask conditioned - draft at sheffields. Dark copper and cloudy pour. Bitter and malty taste. Rich thick palette. A mouthful of a beer, but it is really good. Want to try it not in cask now
January 19, 2013 - bottle shared by BVery.  Dark orange pour with some nice head that lasted.  Caramel and citrus in the aroma and taste.  Thanks Brian for hooking me up with one of my wants!
Bomber. Hazy amber pour with a big fluffy white head and good retention. Caramel, toffee, and citrus in this. Winner.
bottle. amber with two finger head. sweet toasted malt and slightly earthy with substantial hops.

Hazy ish copper with a thin foamy white head. Weird aroma of earthy caramel and oats, with a little honey malt. The flavor had some Irish red malts, earthy caramel, dry oats, and a semi sweet malty finish.  Pleasantly good to drink, though I severely disservice the tasting notes.  It was good.  Thats about all I can pinpoint.

22oz Bottle. The pour was a cloudy reddish amber with an average (1-2 finger) light cream colored frothy head that had great retention, eventually reducing to a thick puddled film with an extra large collar thus producing excellent sheets of lacing.

The aroma was of a sweet caramel malt, herbal hops and a light earthy yeast with notes of citrus (grapefruit), toffee and a light tropical fruity ester (pineapple and mango).

The taste was lightly sweet and rather malty with a nice toffee sweetness early on, and then became mildly hoppy with a bold grapefruit presence and had a nice mild tropical fruitiness towards the end. The flavor hung around for a good long while after the swallow which allowed the hoppy fruity taste to settle in on the taste buds.

Mouthfeel was just past the middle of light to medium in body and was rather dry in texture with a almost ticklish carbonation.

Overall this was a pretty fantastic Red Ale, but then again I would expect nothing less from this brewer...

irish ales never have wowed me, so lets see .. . pours a deep amber ruby .. . great foam, lacing is good too .. . light caramel malts and table syrup .. . light mouth .. . good for an irish ale, but im just averaged on it

.. . . wait? why would you name a beer after a male ice skater??

Poured from a 22oz. bottle into a pint glass

A: Pours a nice hazy amber with some reddish hues in the middle some nice golden edges as well. Frothy half finger white head with a wonderful net lacing left behind. 

S: Light fruits with a nice toasted malt backbone. Sweet honey as well. 

T: Light citrus fruits with a nice dry malt middle. The finish is really great. Light sweet caramel with a smooth faint toffee. Little bitter hop finish at the very brings the ale back home. 

M: Great mouthfeel, light/medium bodied with a crisp finish. Nice medium carbonation with a little toasty oat and bitter hop finish left on the palate. 

O: I thoroughly enjoyed this red ale. Great combination of flavors that go through every range on your palate. It keeps drawing you back for more, and boy did I oblige.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-30-2011

Reddish copper with a thick off white head. The nose shows plenty of piney character along with some sweet peachy notes. Deep, complex palate of black tea, honeyed lemon and caramel. Intensely bitter hopped finish.

A great Irish copper ale.  Not particularly thick on the tongue, but complex and memorable going down.  Had some toasted bread, some sugary sweetness and some pine hops.  A gift from Josh on his way back from WI.

Aroma is fruit, caramel malts and a hint of tropical fruit, similar to a bitter.  The flavor is caramel malts, fruit, mild nuttiness and a lingering bitter and hoppy finish.  A very robust Irish Ale, similar to a bitter/ESB, a great ale.
Hazy amber with thick head. Nice pour. Sweet caramel aroma. Body is sweet caramel, coffee, some nuttiness. Nice balance of sweetness and bitterness.

22oz bottle into a pint glass.

Pours a hazy orange-red with a huge billowy head. Absolutely amazing head retention and lacing. Really some of the best I have ever seen.

Aroma has lots of piney hops perfectly balance by caramel malt. A little toffee as well along with a slight bit of citrus.

The flavor has a shot of piny/citrus hops up front quickly followed by a breeze of coffee before toffee and caramel take hold. Wonderful toast and caramel perfectly balanced by both hop flavor and bitterness. Bitterness is on the high side but doesnt overpower a wonderful toasty finish.

Overall, this really is a wonderful beer. The balance is really as close to perfect as I think you can get. This is my first beer from Three Floyds after finally tracking some down in KY. Not sure when Ill be able to pick up some more but I am very anxious to try some of their other offerings.

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2013 Bottle - thanks Randy! Pours a cloudy amber with a medium creamy tan head that leaves excellent lacing. Aroma is a pleasant blend of caramel, toffee and citric hoppy notes. Flavor is caramel, roasted malts, toffee, citrus, grass, pine and a touch of smoke. Finish is lightly bitter and grassy. Very nice.

Amazing hop aroma, very full, slightly floral. Some hop flavor, but very mild bitterness. Gold color with an amber tint. A little bread in the flavor profile. The star of this beer is all the hop aroma, but a relatively mild beer overall.

Bottle shared at tasting.  Pours clear amber with an off white head.  Aroma of grassy hops, citrus, resin and a little caramel.  Flavour is medium sweet and bitter.  Medium to full bodied with soft to moderate carbonation.

66cl bottle shared with friends.
Lovely hoppy aroma.  Thin white head.  Slightly hazy amber/blond pout. Very nice!

I picked up a bomber of this at 3 Floyds in early 2012 for $8. Pours a dark copper orange with a fluffy head. Scent is hoppy mixed with pineapple delivering a thick, flavorful taste. Very nicely blended that makes for a great sipping beer.
65cl, no mention of ABV, exclusive American brew, thx to Secret Santa!, complex brew, bitter/sweet and slightly fruity/woody, very balanced, clear, rocky head, good brew, yet expensive!

Has some really nice hoppy pine scents as well as toffee and roast notes. Has a rather pleasant pine taste with some malt backbone.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This is red that is definitely representative of what FFF is all about. Pours a clear light amber with thin white head. Aroma is very hoppy and prevalent - citrus, pine and a bit of caramel/toffee. Taste is initially piney hops, but finishes with malty caramel, toffee, and a hint of dark fruit - excellent. Medium to light bodied. I really enjoyed this one and the abundance of hop flavor/aroma certainly makes for an exceptional "red".

Acquired in a Three Floyds super trade around the Dark Lord Release. Stuck it in the fridge and am now enjoying a wine goblet. 

A - Very nice dark brown to amber pour. Solid white tight bubbles that fade quickly.

S - light citrus and pineapple aroma. Kiwi and nutty roasted malts.

T - Up front hop bitterness of Amarillo and Citra hops followed by a big toffee like candy finish thats dark, deep and malty. Very pleasant. 

M - 100% carbonation on the mouth swish. medium body and bitter sweet finish.

O - This is a nice beer! I think 3F has better beers but this one is quite nice. Id get it again but not something Id seek out.
Pours dark orange with creamy white head. Aroma: spruce (intense), pepper, malty caramel, slight vanilla. Taste: spruce, pineapple, caramel, toffee. Somehow thin. Good beer.

Bottle (22 oz.). Thanks to Sean9689! Clear amber/orange with a medium creamy off-white head and nice lacing. A beautiful beer. Aroma of spruce, caramel, sweet coffee and slight pepper and citrus. Taste of spruce and caramel/toffee. Mouthfeel is smooth but a bit thin. Im definitely not a big fan of the style but this one is ahead of everything else of this style that I have tasted so far. Lack a little complexity (one-dimensional beer).
Pours nearly ruby in color.  Good carbonation. Full body with lots of good spices, and flavors. Had a slight caramel taste. Drank on St. Patty?s Day for the full effect.
22 ounce bottle.  Pours a clear dark amber with a large white foamy head.  Aroma of malt, citrus, caramel, and hops.  Taste is malt, citrus hops, caramel, florals, and pine.  Well done!!!
Nice rich full-bodied red. Smooth with notes of spice. Large head and fairly decent amount of carbonation.

Great aroma and flavor. Color is s bit light. Does not fit to style but is an amazing beer! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Scott, split with Pat, Brad and a few other dudes at Capones last year. Poured a light colored red with thin head and lacing. Aromas of citrus, hops, floral pineapple, rye bread and toffee. Taste is orange hop dominant with a nice maltiness in the finish/back side. Smaller notes of vanilla, corn, yeast, caramel, and skunky fuel from the amarillos. Finished crisp with pleasent aftertaste. The best irish beer I have tried so far.

Bomber. Pours clear orange-red with soapy white head. Piney, earthy hops on the nose, with big caramel and slight pineapple as advertised. Very easy drinking, owing to the Irish oats I think, with a smooth malt/hop combo often found in English IPAs. More caramel and toffee tip this into Irish ale territory. Pretty great.

Reddish orange, off white head.  Caramel, nutty, chocolate, and mild lemon aroma and flavor notes.  Full bodied, medium zing and medium bitter finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. So I know it's FFF and all but wasn't too excited about this Irish Ale. Blew my FFFing mind for the style! Almost like an amazingly balanced IPA with sweet toasty caramel maltiness and piney, citrusy, pineapple hoppiness. I really enjoyed this beer. Wish I'd been in a place to do a proper review. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22 oz bottle pours amber with a off white head.  Aroma of roasted malt and pine.  Taste is nice piney hops and caramel malt. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Asked for a sample of it, was given something that tasted like ZD, so ordered more. Then got it actually and it is okay but not one of FFFs stronger efforts.

Fantastic beer.  Never had an irish red anywhere near this caliber.  Great spicy, floral, citrus hops accent a nice malty sweetness that brings caramel and a rich nutty backbone.  Could drink this beer all the time.
Extra toasty red malty beer. Mild and delicious. This is tasty, great stuff

Pours a dark murky orangish red with a yellow tinted white head, tons of it with tight bubbles leaving a thick lace. The nose is sweet and grainy with a slightly off twang to it. The grain smells stale and the hops oily with a fleshy orange peel. The taste has a huge toasted malt and chocolate malt flavor that was unexpected. The hop presence is much lighter than in the nose and actually more balanced. Lightly citric and bitter with a moderate sweetness, crisp finish with an assertive carbonation.

Bottle pours clear thin light amber with an off white head. Head quickly disappears. Aromas are malty and hoppy. Tastes are fruity and malty and very well balanced. Body is light and the beer is very sessionable. Overall a very good red ale. Happy to have it anytime.

poured from bottle into a pint glass. Pours a medium orange color with a small head.

Good complex aromas of apricots, hops, toffee and some malts as well. Decent depth too.

Medium/full bodied with good flavors of apricots, malts, toffee and a touch of hops. Almost all attack though as it falls off on the mid and finish a slight bit.

A very good beer, but somewhat middle of the road for 3f.

Thanks to FullObs.  Thick fading head.  Dark amber and slightly cloudy.  Full body and palate.  Nose probably better than an 7, but was a bit subdued.  Pleasing sweet caramel malts and floral hops.  Sweet up front, nice balancing bitterness, and sweet, clean finish. Great balance, really enjoyable and nice to see a beer this good at a lower alcohol.  Not particularly Irish, but whatever.

As I came home on Friday night, as drunk as drunk can be, I saw strong hops in my pint of red where mild hops should be...so I calls the wife and I says to her, will you kindly tell to me, who owns strong hops in my old red where mild hops should be.
I dont care for Irish Reds, maybe thats because Killians Red butter bombs have ruined my enthusiasm.  But this one, with its hops and great flavor just solidify my Three Floyds love even more.

Served on tap in a pint glass.

The trademark Three Floyds signature creamy cap sits on top of the fuzzy amber beer.  Tightly wound sheets of lace leave a beer level history down the side of the glass.

The aroma is not outrageously hoppy per se, but it does have a much hoppier nose than the Irish Red style it supposedly is.  Toasted bread and caramel bring in some spice, juicy grapefruit, and a bit of tropical fruit.

The flavors really pack a punch, especially considering the comparatively low ABV.  Toaste grain and bread really control the flavor, with some caramel and toffee notes adding a touch of sweetness.  Next the hops really begin to take off.  There is a nice grapefruit citrus kick with a strong pineapple and general tropical fruit presence.  The hops are bitter, but they never entirely take over, leaving a strongly flavored, hop-centric but balanced Irish Red in the end.

Compared to the style, the body feels on the fuller, creamier side.  The carbonation is smooth and gently scrubs the remaining hop oils off the tongue after each sip.  

This does not get the name recognition as some of the other Three Floyds beers do, but it is definitely a solid Irish Ale.

Draught at Three Floyds Brewpub. Clear deep red/amber - white head. Nice hoppy, nelson hoppy, petroleum, caramel, light sweet malty, toasted, bisquit, citrus, toffee, cereal notes. Very nice, not very irish.

Oh gosh this one is a hop bomb. Im pretty no lad from Ireland has had anything quite like this. I call shinanigans on the Irish Ale bit. But either way it is red and has an enormous amount grapefruit, bright citrus, lemons, oranges, other bright citrus and an evident element of rich toasty and toffee/nutty caramel malts. Flavor again lend bright aromatic and grassy hops and te malts toffee and nutty character come through a little more. This is quite the hoppy red ale treat. love it even though Three Floyds are arrogant bastard fucks.

Bomber poured into an English Pint.  Amber colored brew with a honey-colored hue.  Two finger egg shell head that fades slowly and leaves a splotchy but thick lace.  Very hoppy fragrance.  Bitter orange peel and a slight Earthiness and even slighter caramel malt.  I was expecting the taste to follow suit but an ashy malt actually hits first followed by Earthy hops and bitter resin.  I think i actually would have liked if the flavors resembled the aroma more closely.  Somewhat thin palate but very drinkable and quenching.  Overly hopped for the style but not a bad twist if you like hops.

22 oz. bottle. Pours clear dark amber with a foamy tight off white head that rests to a sudsy film. Aroma is bright fruity citrus hops like pineapple and grapefruit and faint caramel sugar malt. Taste is bitter fruity hops and malt that comes off dry and musty. Palate is medium with an abundance of carbonation and finishes chalky dry. Awesome hop forward Irish Ale.

A - Pours a super clear copper-red with a finger of frothy tannish head. The head fades down fairly slowly leaving behind some good lace.

S - Aroma is a mix of grapefruit and citrus hops with some strong pine notes, sweet caramel malts, and a bit of toasted bready notes.

T - Starts off with some citrus hops with some grapefruit and some light bitterness and some sweet toasted malts in the background. Through the middle, the malts come through a bit stronger with some biscuit and pine malts as well. The finish is a mix of pine and citrus hops with some bitterness, sweet biscuity malts, and a bit of floral flavor.

M - Medium-plus bodied with moderate carbonation. Smooth with a sweet, resiny, and light bitter finish.

D - Very drinkable. Excellent red ale with a bit more hops than normal for the style. The balance is really nice and the beer has a great malty profile.

Deep amber pour with white, thick head. Huge intense hop aroma, some fruitiness. As always with 3F, excellent hop flavor. Not out of balance toward bitterness either. Caramel malt character, without a trace of astringency, but good.  Overall, another great beer from FFF.  Wonderful flavor with some citrus notes, tasty hoppiness.
Not exactly an authentic Irish Red but delicious none-the-less. It has all the typical 3F characteistics of hops and citrus. Could drink this stuff all day.

Poured into a perfect pint.

4.5 A: Clear medium orange color. Two and a half fingers of off-white, dense creamy head. Retention is better than average and plenty of lacing is left.

4.5 S: This is hopped to hell and back. Mango and pineapple dominate the nose. Underneath there is a slight amount of toffee, oat, and caramel. Super clean. Not the most complex, but thats because the hops cover up mostly everything. Smells wonderful nonetheless.

3.5 T: Tasty, but its lacking the typical red ale flavors for the most part. The hops again dominate, leaving little room for caramel and toffee to shine. Mild bitterness. 3.5 D: This is more like Alpha King than an actual Irish Red Ale. Oh well, its tasty, but I was expecting an Irish ale so Im a bit disappointed.

one of the better Irish ales I have had. Usually found around St. Pats Day. Sweet smell and a touch sweet on the smell. A decent brew worth giving a try. Notes from this tasting were damaged, that was all I could decifer.

I like the aromas and the flavors, but do they belong in a sessionable Irish ale? Of course, this is a question for someone who views things objectively, and that person is not me. Subjectively, this beer was expensive and hard to acquire, so I am pleased that it reflects FFFs signature hopping style rather than being boring. I dont care how inappropriate that may be to the style. It was good, and I enjoyed it.

(22oz bottle courtesy of jcnd9803!).  Pours clear amerber color with white head and nice carbonation. Aroma has lots of pine/citrus-grapefruit and guava-and a hint of cardboard. Bomber poured into a tulip.  Pours a clear red/amber with thin white lacing that dissipates quickly.  Aromas are full of citrus.  Hops dominate the taste.  Not as malty as other irish ales Ive had.  Mouthfeel is medium to light.  Not my favorite 3 F beer.
