22 oz. bomber brought back from the Liquor Stop by,and shared with my son.  a deep rich mahogany in color with a great looking off-white head.  aroma is of caramel, spice and and some citrus notes. a somewhat spicey almost bitter flavor of caramel, toffee nut and hops.  a very drinkable amber.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2006 Head is initially small, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing.  Body is hazy dark amber. Aroma is lightly to moderately hoppy (resin, grapefruit), lightly to moderately malty (toasted bread, caramel), lightly yeasty (dough). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.

Bomber:  Three Floyds needs to get some new caps, this violet and lime combo is a little fruity.  Good looking beer, large head, lasting.  Sweet citrus nose.  Flavor was fruit and very hoppy, noticably hoppy at that.  Finishes clean for the most part, some lasting fruity bitterness.
Bomber. Pours a nice red with foamy white head., Nose is hoppy and fruity, like citrus but a little more sweet and less acidic. Sweet fruit and hopps stand out in the moouth w a smooth, clean palate.

Poured reddish amber with hints of orange as well.  Good tan head with typical three floyds lacing.  Aroma had toffee, caramel, graitfruit, courant and citrus.  Taste was mostly dominated by caramel and courant.  There was some graitfruit especially in the aftertaste.  Good bitter mouthfeel.  Very nice stuff.

Pours burnt orange with moderate tannish head.  Nose is flowery and hoppy with citrusy zest.  Flavor screams of caramel and maltyness.  Medium body with underlyingbitterness.  This is a very nice beer.  There is a pleasant balance between the hop presence and the toffeeish/caramel flavor.

22 oz bottle:  Reddish Amber w/ a lasting medium sized cream colored head.  First whiff is of Lipton instant iced tea mix w/ lemon.  Citrusy lemon hop aroma as well as an herbal and grassy fresh hop aroma.  Bready dried malt w/ some grainy malt and hints of caramel.  Well balanced but a bit on the sweet side up front, but  a bit of bitterness comes into the medium sweet finish & lasts into the lingering aftertaste.  Very little caramel character overall, bland malt profile with a bit of herbal hop.  Lower level of carbonation, smooth, and medium bodied.  Not a bad Irish Red, but I was expecting more from 3 Fs.  As in true 3Fs fashion, it was mostly about the hops.

22 oz bomber.  This one came straight from Indiana via cousin in law Mike Schreffler.  Pours with a fluffy head and a reddish amber color that is good and dark and good lace.  Nose is almost perfect with a pine - citrus - grapefruit - toffee - caramel sweetness.  The aroma is so great, its a shame to drink it... but I will.  Taste is immediate malt, actually with a little smoked taste and it is followed by pineapple and toffee, then some burnt sugar sweetness.  Cookie dough follows for just a second and then come the hops!  Beautiful, fully blended perfectly chosen hops along with a biscuit like quality.  What flavor!  Great body as well, with high carbonation (which probably doesnt really fit the style, but I like it).  This renews my faith in 3 Floyds after that awful Gumball Head experience.  Good work!

mmmmm.... something about the aroma of a 3F beer.  hadnt had a three floyds brew in a while so this hit the spot.  pours red with a nice tight head.  citrus hops still dominate even though i know that this probably isnt as fresh as when bottled in the spring.  smooth, carmelly and fruity.  another winner.

Amber with orange highlights, film of a white head.  Amarillo hops dominate the aroma, with some sweet maltiness behind it.  Mellow citrus and floral grassiness of Amarillo hops combines with husky crisp malt flavors, some toastiness and a dash of caramel.  Finish is slightly astringent with lingering caramel sweetness.  Mouthfeel is medium light with excellent crispness.

22oz bottle: Mostly clear dirty amber with garnett highlights when held to light.  Theres a large light tan head that lasts as long as youre willing to wait.  The aroma is a solid buttery, caramel, biscuit malt with some fruity pineapple/grass/berry/pine hops and a hint of strawberries.  Tastes has some nice caramel/toffee malt sweetness up front that is immediately followed by pineapple & bread, buttery grass, spicy mild chocolate, and a bit of bitter roasted malt towards the finish.  Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, feels almost watery up front then fades to an oily syrupy mouth feel - strange progression, I know.  Theres a bit of yeast taste in there as it warms that really reminds me of dark lord as well.

Clear amber with compact but foamy head, very sticky lace - piney, hoppy aroma, with some toasty, biscuity malts and a hint of strawberry - medium-bodied - medium sweet, balanced with moderate hop bitterness - floral and herbal at first, then some light fruit and mildly sweet, bready flavors - somewhat ESB-like - not bad, but FFF makes much better.

Thick, frothy, beige head on a nice-looking red body.  Great hoppiness, slightly sweet and slightly bitter aroma, like an ESB would have.  The flavor is also very hoppy for an Irish Red, but it finishes very thin, as though it is quite watered down.  Minerals, caramel and earthy tones.

Damn!!!  I loved this beer.  It had to be the best red ale I have ever had.  I have wanted one ever since and I cant get it in my area and its only available for St. Patricks Day.  I told the company they should offer it all the time.  Its basicly a red ale with a strong hop flavor.  If you like reds and you havent had one, get one next March.

Sampled from a bomber I picked up in Madison.  Pours to a thin white head oil-slick head atop a reddish brown body.  Good lacing.  The aroma is very huge.  Mostly pine/spruce/grapefruit/pineapple with a touch of lemoned iced tea.  Why cant all boring amber ales smell more like this.    The flavor is pineapple and iced tea made with mineral water.  Amarillo hoppiness.  The palate is medium bodied and decent.  I think this is probably the best amber ale that Ive had.

Thanks to Blake for sharing.
a light red copper color lots of carb bubbles rising a small very thick off white head not much lacing.  Scent is strong a big citrus hop aroma and a nice carmel and some odd fruit scent too that I couldnt identify.  Palate is very carbonated decent coating.  Flavor is an odd bitter kind of piney mixed w/ that bad carbonated water stuff its not bad but I dont like it much at all.

The first thing I noticed when I poured this ale is (are) the hops. Citrus and pine. Never experienced a head described as sticky, but this one definitely is. It has a darker than average cream color, stays around a while and produces a good lace. The citrus from the aroma shows up in the initial taste, but dissipates. There is no piney flavor to this one (to me, thats a good thing). It is colored like iced tea with a hint of amber. The taste is only average. Its not bad by any means, but there is more to the appearence and aroma than to the flavor. Only an initial hint of malt then slightly appealing bitterness. Definite drying finish and hop burps.

Deep coppers and orange,  creamy off white head.  Nose was very nice with tones of iced tea, caramel, citrus, fresh bread dough, and light pine.  For 3Fs, this was a pleasant surprise when I found it extremely well balanced, hopped tea and citrus flavors on the front, but a nice earthy sweet caramel malt backbone to stand on in the end.  Medium bodied,  soft carbonation, drying citrusy tea like finish.  A very nice session brew if only I didnt have to go to Chicago to pick it up!

#300.  Pour is a deep amber/copper under a whte head.  Aroma is surprisingly hoppy -- some nice spicy, fruity notes -- pineapple, citrus.  The aroma is definitely malt dominant, however, with sweet caramel and amber coming through.  Flavor is very rich, sweet malt that maintains its sweetness in the finish, even though it is very well balanced by some citrussy hops.  Really solid even though its not my favorite style.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2006 Bottle... Clear copper ale with a mid-sized, creamy, khaki head. Excellent retention. The nose is of caramel, spruce, pink grapefruit and light cocoa. Well-balanced for a Three Floyds brew... not crazy hopped. Very lightly malty and medium bitter with hints of milk chocolate and caramel. Medium-bodied and astringent with lively carbonation. Finishes bone dry.

Bomber.  Pours a deep reddish copper with a large off-white head.  Aroma was malty with bread and caramel notes and tangerine like hop aromas.  Other fruitiness is present as well.  Tastes of full malty doughiness with some sweet crystal malt to balance along with a generous amount of citrusy hop flavor.  Bitterness is quite subtle but still present.  Extensive esters of tropical fruit and apple and citrus.  Body is full and smooth with moderate carbonation.  Good beer, though a bit out of style for an Irish red given the assertive hops, but hey, who cares.  Man, even in moderate styles, Three Floyds does nothing but impress.

Great red ale if you like some good assertive hop character. Beautiful red with thin tan head. Fresh hoppy aroma complemented by some sweet malt and fruit...some citrus and hints of pineapple for sure. More caramel malty sweetness mixed with those delicious hops. Very nice.

Im sitting in my house watching the backyard get pounded by a Nebraska-sized thunderstorm with golf ball-sized hail careening off the deck ... so its time to drink a big beer!  This is a nice ruddy orange-red color with a cumulus poofy off-white head.  The aroma is a seducing floral hop bouqet.  The beer feels a bit too light on the tongue, but this is a nice marriage of American-style hoppiness with a thin veil of caramel underpinning.  Quite yummy.

Bomber.  Pours a deep amber with a nice lasting beige head.  Aroma is skewed towards the amarillo hops but there is still some caramel malt aroma as well.  Flavor is nice and sweet, full of malt presence- lots of crystal and maybe munich?  Also a lot of hops in the flavor but not overdone.  Nice moderately bitter finish.  I liked this amber ale overall.  Fits the american amber category- not even close to an irish red.

06.18.05 Bomber.  The pour is a reddish copper with typical lofty white FFF head.  In fact, other than the blast of Amarillo, the appearance is the only thing that is typically FFF about this beer.  Aroma is pineapple candy, chocolate chip cookie, earth.  Im pretty sure I smell cat piss, too, but that might just be the neighbors cat.  The body is thin, typical for an amber, I guess, but not what I expected for my seven bucks.  Its not just thin, its fleeting.  The punch of hops is short-lived as well, quickly giving way to a mild and disoriented earth/grape/sulfur sweetness.  Oh, I definitely smell cat piss in this beer.  Finishes with wet paper notes laced with sticky pineapple, mineral, and honeyed tea.  Lingering sweatsock.  Im not at all pleased with this brew.

22 ounce bottle. Sitting on the deck drinking a good red ale listening to the Reds play the Red Sox. The beer has been much better. Amber red hue with medium head. Good non-complex aroma. Medium body with medium finish. Well balanced flavor with hoppy dry finish. Very good brew.

Bottle: Dark caramel, reddish hues, slight haze, moderate to small foamy off-white head, fairly attractive lacing, decent carbonation. &nbsp Raisiny aroma, sweet tobacco, a little bit of malted peat, subtle hop presence, all while being fairly malty. &nbsp Loads more tobacco, long cut chew actually, on the tongue. &nbsp Malty as well, with the soft raisin character following through. &nbsp Moderate body and mouthfeel. &nbsp Clean finish, lingering tobacco like flavors. &nbsp Seems to have a bit more hop bitterness, albeit subtle, on the finish. &nbsp Brings me back to the days when I worked at a lumbar yard... <chew - spit> &nbsp Im surprised nobody else mentioned this... I guess nobody else ever dipped in their life? &nbsp Thanks MAP!

If you are a fan of amarillo hops (Gumballhead) then you will also like this brew.
Nice malty backbone... Not much hop bitterness but lots of aroma/flavor.
I am not a fan of amarillo hops, I was hoping they brewed this with some other hop.

Poured a medium and slightly hazy brownish-red color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of stronger pine, pineapple, oranges and light caramel. Tastes of caramel, toffee, and pine (not as strong as the aroma) and a pineapple finish to it. Nice hoppy character to it.

As would be predicted a nice hop aroma as soon as you crack it open. Pours out a nice reddish color with a nice foamy head. The taste is hoppy but well balanced by sweet malty flavors. This is my type of red ale!

Nice pale red color. Toffee roasted caramel malts are the dominant flavor with a nice hop bitterness lingering in the backround to compliment. Comes across very dry with minimal malt sweetness. Definetely one of the more flavorful red ales I have tried. Pretty solid, but loses some points for chalky mouthfeel.

Bottle courtesy of Wohlfs. Pours dark ruby with no head. Aroma has lots of citrus hop with some sweet malt background. Flavor has lots of caramel malt, with some bread character and a decent hop finish. Pleasantly surprised by this "amber".

Auburn in color. Sustained but puffy beige-tinged foam. Modestly aromatic, with mandarin oranges, green raisins, and lightly roasted nuts. Very subtle notes of lemon zest, and pungently earthy hops. Loosely woven carbonation. Opens with a gritty resin flash, but mostly slickly fruity with dull berry and tropical fruit notes. Smooth-edged nuttiness curbs the sharper roasted malt hull underlay. Glassy acidic tingle at the sides of the cheeks. Slight chalky airiness disperses much of the bodys denseness. Malts become quite husky as it warms, compounding the mushy body and undefined hop character. Finishes timidly hoppy, with an equilibrium of bready, nutty malt accents. Faint citrus hop burps. Overall, the hops severely lack that FFFs hallmark definition, and the body is too mushy. Pretty straightforward.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: amber, small white head.  big fruity and hoppy aroma with orange and mixed citrus, biscuit and hard candy.  sticky coating mouthfeel.  flavour is sweet, caramelly and mildly earthy.  bitterness finishes quickly

Aroma - all the hops that would be expected from a 3F beer.  Very Fresh.  Appearance is copper, with a significant eggshell head.  Tastes far less hopped than it smells, with caramel and peat dominating.  Finish is short and unspectacular. Thanks KP

Red color with a nice looking, medium head.  Aroma is tons of fresh hops and then some.  Flavor is overwhelmed by piney, mildly earthy hops and background caramel and toffee.  A better "irish red", but I still havent found one that makes my mouth water.

Deep red color with no head.  Strong hops aroma.  Good lord... its all hops.  Tastes like Im brushing my teeth with a pine branch.  A little overdone on the hops, to say the least.  Some malt hiding in the background.

Poured a reddish amber color with a large, off white head that left thick lacing on the glass.  Aroma of citrus and resiny pine, sweet malt as well.  weet caramel and toffee, pine as well in the taste.  Bitter grapefruit finish.

Thin looking brownish red with a fairly creamy, quick dissapearing head.  It has the expected Three Floyds hop character; nice floral and citrus hop aromas.  A little bit sweet, and nice character.  There is a sweet malt and slight roastyness followed by a mild hop.   Sweet, then quickly bitter.  Very nice clean quality beer, as is expected from 3Fs.

Clear amber body and off-white head. Aroma has a brown sugar, malty quality and a cinnamon, fruity hop character. Flavor gives the impression of spiced, stale tea and includes some husky astringency as if from burnt grain husks. Subpar by Three Floyds standards.

HUGE hop aroma, i didnt even need to get my nose near the glass to smell it, very  strong and possibly the only beer i can think of that smelled bitter.  also some citrus aroma coming off an amber body with a cream colored head. flavor is outstanding balance, the caramel malts are the backbone of the taste, with bitter hops softly leading the way and coming on a little more strongly at the end, the actual aftertaste is sweet and caramel, nice body, hints of citrus every where but nothing overpowering.  a very smooth, easy to drink ale.  thanks to bbb63 for this.
22 0z bomber. Clear orange in color with a nice tan head. Very hoppy aroma. American hops. Very fresh. Malty hoppy flavor. Smooth tasting. Finish is hoppy.  Very fresh. Nice beer. Enjoyable.

22 oz bomber. Clear ruby orange with a nice tan head. Very hoppy fresh aroma. Love them Amarillos. Smooth malty hoppy flavor, with a hoppy flavor finish. Not too bitter. Nice carmel malts. Very fresh.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Poured a clear amber color.  Huge hop aroma, ctrus and floral.  Malty flavor with caramel and a light bitter finish.  Very nice beer.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2007 This is a really good beer.  Its a less intense Alpha King but with all the floral aroma.  Surprisingly light bodied, but that be because I drank it after a Dark Lord.  Smooth and clean with that typical Three Floyds hop flavor.  Highly recommended but not as good as Alpha King
Reddish brown color, caramel, toffee, and citrus hops all over this brew. Very drinkable.

Pours a rich dark red with a small light tan head that gives way to lacing.  Strong hops aromas, grapefruit citrus, anise, and some toffee.  Palate is a little too smooth and the flavor dissipates on the finish.  Flavors are strong and well-balanced, however, with caramel, toffee, and rough-n-ready hops that contribute some bitterness.  Of course, if there was a rating category for the name of the brew, this one would score even higher.

Translucent amber in color with a bubbly and thin grey/tan head.  Quite a hoppy aroma - floral hop bouquet is nicely met with traces of pine, honey and maple.  Delicious.  This beer is a total palate cleanser.  Pineapple, mango and pine join with an unexpected bitter edge, along with some subtle traces of nuts that hint toward an Irish red ale rendition.  Kind of slips in and out, chafing the tongue with the traditional Three Floyds hop machine while caramel malts come to the forefront to help solidify and provide more body.

Pours amber with and off white head.  Awesome hop presence in the aroma. Citrus with a strong pineapple nose. Well balanced brew. Strong malt body complimented by a good hop character. Body is rich and creamy yet goes down ever so smoothly. Flavor is initially malty with a hint of caramel, and then changes and finishes with hops. Strong citrus taste throughout, mostly pineapple and grapefruit. Good lingering hop finish with sour citrus notes.

Clear reddish body, thick, puffy beige head.  Whaddaya know?  Big piney, grapefruity, rindy hops aroma with hints of caramel and toast.  Rather thin-bodied, light, and caramely, with toast and a touch of cheerios attempting to subdue the grapefruit and pine hops notes.  They largely succeed.  Actually, this is quite pleasant and quaffable, a solid session beer from 3Fs.  Thanks humulus for the bottle!

Happy to find this in a wine shop in Williamsburg.  Medium red amber appearance, nice, lasting tan head.  Big aroma of pineapple, very appealing.  Flavor matched.  The malts were balancing, faintly of caramel, but the hop steal the show without being overpowering.  Pineapple, with a touch of grapefruit on the finish.  This was fantastic, far better than I had expected from the relatively lukewarm reviews here.
UPDATED: MAY 9, 2005 Bottle: poured orange/red, kind of an iced tea color. Moderate beige head. Hug grassy hop aroma, pineapple, pine. Flavor is all hops-grass, pine. Decent body. Very good beer.

Golden amber hue with a white, frothy, medium head.  Huge grassy, piney, citric hop aroma.  Caramel malts.  Moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter flavor becomes a lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter finish.  Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.  The bottom line is: flavor completely disappears on the back end?

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2005 Bottle.  Pours a transparent amber, off white head.  Aroma of fruity, juicy hops.  Amarillo.  Just from the aroma you can tell its a 3F beer.  Flavor is quite balanced.  Very caramelly finish.  Average for what this brewer can do, but thats not saying much, really.  This is very nice beer.  Cool label.

22 oz bomber thanks to Npdempse for hooking me up with 2 of these a few weeks ago.  Pours a nice red hue with a nice white head, almost off-white.  big citric, grapefruit, pinneapple dry hopped aroma with notes of peach and apricot in there as well.  Amarillo heaven!  Some citric flavors start then finishes with a caramel note from the malts.  My only complaint is that the flavors here seem very tame, even moreso than say gumballhead.  The body is fizzy for three floyds standards.  I think maybe they were trying to cover up something with all the dry hops. hmmmmmm......  Short finish.  still leaves good lacing on my glass.  Still overall, a good three floyds beer, but just not as good as alot of them in their lineup.

dark brown, without much head.  i caught too much pine in the aroma.  a bitter, evergreeny flavor, which i enjoyed.  oily palate, nice on back of throat.  i didnt enjoy as much as alpha king, but a refreshing brew nonetheless.
This a good amber ale.  Citric, pineapple, and caramel flavors.  Finishes clean crisp, and dry.

Deep clear amber color with  a generous off white head.
Fresh clean pine aroma.
Full body, malty and well balanced flavor. This one is well done, especially for a style which is often boring and predictable. Thanks to Sprinkle for this!
On tap at the brewery. Brown/reddish color. malty/piney aroma. Malty with piney hops flavor. Caramelly. Pretty tasty.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2008 Bottle. Thick, rich clear amber color with a lasting head that produces nice lace. Nice floral hop aroma. Taste is biscuit, citrus hops and fruits (pineapple, tangerine and apple). Chewy hops abound along with toffee and caramel. Some peat but if there is any, it gets overwhelmed. Very nice.

Clear reddish amber with a dense beige head. Caramel, pineapples and flowers in the soft malty aroma. Clean sweet malty and aromatic flavour of caramel, toffee, peaches and caramel. Hop bitter finish. Well balanced ale.

Bottle. Small sized ivory head that was mostly lasting, fair lacing, fine-small sizee bubbles, softly carbonated, and transparent. Malt, caramel, hoppy, citrus notes, and pineapple aroma. Flavor was malty sweet and hoppy. Hoppy mouthfeel. This one was too hoppy for my palate.

Pours a clear dark amber with a frothy and well-lacing off-white head.  Has a very nice, fresh, green hoppy aroma with some pine up front and sweet toffee and caramel malt supporting it.  Body starts with a pleasant malty sweetness and good hoppy balance leading to a crisp, semi-dry finish.  Probably too hoppy to be considered a true amber, but I dont care.  Thanks EddieG!

Red/brown with a diminishing, lacing tan head. Beautiful, sweet nose with flowers (violets), apricots, and musty and grassy notes. Tangy flavor, medium sweet, nutty, with some fruity (orange, apricot) hop tones. Fairly bitter. Good session stuff, though it has something of a cloying aftertaste.

Bottle:  Real light malt and grapefruit aroma.  Pours dark transparent amber with a white head.  Malty up front with a moderate fruity orange and grapefruit hop finish.  Seems more like an APA than an amber.  Thanks to wolhfs.

2005 bottle shared at the 4/17/05 Montreal tasting among Muzzlehatch, MartinT, tiggmtl, Rastacouere, Beerbuzzmontreal, Olivier and Simon.  Pours a clear red-orange-amber, not particularly deep or hugely colorful, tending more towards ambery-copper.  Small off-white head is not long retained.  Aroma of dry hops, lightly floral, hints of grapefruit rind, a touch of biscuits and very brief glimpses of caramel.  Flavor begins with strong, drying hops.  Dry, very NOT flavorful and just astringent.  Some notes of biscuits, stale brown bread and lightly toasted grains.  Hints of grapefruit rind again, faint touches of honey and then water. . .soda water, that is (too much carbonation).  Medium-light body, lack of malt kills any chance of me getting excited about this.  Reminds me of Robert the Bruce (wheres the thick malting!).  I dont know what excuse there could be, this bottle was no doubt taken care of and it is only a few months old.  Maybe they just wanted to brew a grapefruit rind beer.  Enough with this crap, Im ready for Dark Lord!

22 oz bottle consumed with beerbuzzmontreal, ClarkVV, MartinT, tiggmtl, olivier, Rastacouere and Simon at the Farmhouse Ales and More! tasting in Montreal.  Coppery relatively clear body with just a bit of head...nice hefty smoky/pungent leafy-hoppy nose, fairly dry...body alas very watery and thin, caramel flavor and touches of roastiness almost lost in the overwhelming boredom...huge disappointment from this great brewer.

Bottled. Clear ruby, brief head. Rich lychee aroma. Light to medium bodied with very clean mouthfeel. Some crystal malt flavour beneath a fluffy blanket of aromatic hops. Bitter, yet aromatic finish. Nice, but one-dimensional.

Very strong, leafy, orange, pine, herbal hop nose with strong underlying sweetness.  Very clear amber-copper with decent tan head that recedes to cover with some lace.  Orange, perfume-like, hops with a very bland malt character and rather harsh, strong bitterness.  Perhaps a light, shy, toasty note creeps in as it warms, but maybe that was wishful thinking.  Medium-light body is somewhat watery and perhaps a touch thin and puckering.  Bottle sampled with beerbuzzmontreal, ClarkVV, MartinT, muzzlehatch, olivier, Rastacouere and Simon.

Orange-amber body, lasting beige ring. Rather dull aroma, this seems so simple and feels like déjà vu as much as anything else. Ample grapefruity/tangerine like hops dominate (while being fairly fragile) the leafy and rocky aroma. Mineral palate, thin-medium bodied, highly carbonated. Very dry palate boasting more astringent hops than is recommendable. Very earthy, herbal (lichen, algae).. Those hops feels raw and attaches to the palate, this is not aggressive, its just dull in the same sense than a fly you want to push away. I do like dreadnaught and alpha king, but I dont recognize 3 floyds here

Whatever, Three Floyds.  Basically a session ale with a hop overlay.  Pours red and with little head.  Aroma is 90% grapefruit hops, 5% maple and 5% standard malt.  Flavor is hoppy with a slight sweetness.  I wish I could find more descriptive terms, but it more a lack of flavor than vocabulary.  Another tragic attempt to artificially inflate the flavor of a beer with sleezy hops.  This is not an Irish Ale, it is an IPA, and a sub-par one at that.  It leaves me pondering, what would this beer be without hype?

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2007 The Lure:Perfumy, citrusy hops rise from the earth. A peach syrup is used to make the grow.

The Festivities:Citrus fruit glisten even after having fallen on the wet soil. Cherry pits are found amongst the watery beads. The fizzy carbonation does point more towards Amber Ale than Irish Red.

Transcendence:Definitely not as proud and boastful as the character on its label, yet for the style...

Pours a red color with a ring of white lace. Good aroma and flavor of malt, hops and caramel. Light to medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation. Its good but not up to Three Floyds usual standards.

Thich light tan head of fine bubbles.  Light carbonation.  Rich and creamy head reforms upon swirling.  Wonderful aroma.  Plentiful hops with lots of citrus and pineapple.  Making my mouth salivate just smelling it.  Some roasted grains in there also.  Color is a very dark amber/red and is slightly cloudy.  Big on the hops again.  Lots of citrus and a bit of pine.  Very dry palate.  Light roastyness again but is overpowered by the hops.  Which is fine if you are a hop head.  FInish is dry and  a little bit chalky.  Good bitterness and the pine lingers around for a while.  An excellent amber ale.

Copper/red color with a foamy off white head.  The usual citrus nose that you expect from Three Floyds.  As the beer warms, a pleasant maltiness with hints of dark crystal malt and chocolate emerge.  Smooth beer on the palate.  Fresh citrusy flavors, with a nice malty backdrop.  If anything, this may be a touch thin.  Intresting take on the style.  Kind of like taking a 12oz. Conways Irish Ale, adding 3oz. of water, and garnishing the pint with a wedge of grapefruit.

Pours dark red with a tan head that sticks around.  A good hoppy citrus and malt aroma.  Flavor is mostly hops but some malt flavor as well.  Very smooth on the palate and a fantastic brew.  Ill drink this one again for special occasions!
a very tasty amber quality that tingles a little bit.  subtle floral undertones that give it a tangy quality.

22oz bottle. Amber color with a small off white head. Aroma is mostly hops and grapefruit with some sweet malt.
Flavor is again dominated by the hops.
Citrusy hop flavor with a small malt background. Maybe not perfectly balanced but very delicious.

The brew poured a nice hazy dark amber with a thin head on top.  Even my mon can detect: "hops! hops!"  when it got close to here nose.  Whis about all I can smell as well.  Flavor is strong with the hops as well, but there is certainly a good presence of some malt, but it really is taking the backseat to the hops.

I have to say I was thoroughly impressed with this beer. It pours a nice red/amber with a slight head.  The smell is of wonderful dry hops.  The taste is nice with carmel followed by citrus. Excellent beer.
Light amber in color with a medium off-white head. Aroma of earthy hops and citrus. Flavor is of caramel and citrus.
You gotta like this high alpha hop character in the aroma . This amber ale is hop oriented , but not only . I does have enough bready malt to balance thing out. Full, high quality ale. Very good.
Pour was dark amber.  aroma was sweet with caramel and a nice hoppy hint.  Taste was bascially alot like all of 3 Floyds brews taste.  Finish was pretty good.  Not a favorite, but steady enough.

(22oz bottle) Clear copper body with small beige head.  Aroma is moderately sweet, grapefruit, some pineapple, caramel, light tangerine.  Taste is medium sweet, grapefruit, some pineapple, light caramel.  Definitely plenty of hops, but not especially bitter.  Watery medium body, some resin.  No idea why 3Fs considers this an Irish red -- tastes like an APA, a very good one at that.

22 oz. brown bomber bottle. Poured out a medium amber color, with a sticky tan colored head. Slid back to a thick mat of foam on top of the beer. Left gobs of sticky lacing down the sides of the glass. Aromas are of sweet caramel malts, slight chocolate nose, biscuity malts, some yeast, and citrus. Hop aromas are slightly subdued, but present all the same. Flavors are of sweet malt, some bready flavors, and a dry finish to it. A really decent amber ale overall.

22 oz bottle pours a clear bright amber with a creamy off white head that leaves lots of lacing in my glass. Citrus fruity aromas, pineapple, grapefruit and caramel flavors. Unlike any Irish Ale I have ever had. Medium bodied with a somewhat watery mouthfeel, finishes bitter, this is very tasty.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2005 On tap at Clark Street Ale House in Chicago. The head was slightly yellowish with a beautiful amber coloring. The aroma is sweet caramel and you know the hops profile of Three Floyds. Strong oranges with a touch of pine. The taste is sweet toasted caramel. The body is light with wood and a touch of pine. Very nicely done. Tried this agian in the bottle after it aged a few months. Slightly more mellow. Still, very nicely done.

Very pretty red amber color with not much head.  Lots of hops in the aroma, but not sharp.  More of a mellow hop character.  Well balanced with malt.  Really nice flavor. Not an Amber ale though.  Three floyds has a problem with style.

Brigh amber-red colour.  Massive, one-dimensional amarillo aroma has my yawning.  Sweet, warming body with hints of caramel and some well-extracted malts.  Balanced by soft, woody hops.  Slightly acidic finish.  Despite the overblown dry-hopping, its actually a pretty tasty beer.

Pours reddish orange color with a big totally retained off white head.  Aroma is BIG Amarillo hop presence, very christmas tree like aroma.  Flavor is caramel malt with a bit of hops, but not near as much hop flavor as the aroma would suggest.  A bit of spiciness as well.  Obviously about as good as ambers get, and eminently sessionable.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2007 I am continually surprised by the subtlety of this beer.  A complex malty beer with a gorgeous red color.  Beer is hoppy at the nose but not so in the flavor.  Actually a significant malt presence is felt with a toasty flavor reminiscent of the old Chicago Brewing Red Ale.  Definately drinkable, not overbearing and worthy of this rerate.

Beautiful glowing fiery amber with a big off-white head. Great aroma of pineapple, citrus and piney hops and caramel. Flavor has notes of caramel, grapefruit, pine and then gives way to pineapple and tropical fruits. Pleasantly sweet. Given the hoppiness, the taste is surprisingly not that bitter at all. Very well-balanced. Has a lingering fruity finish. Medium body with a silky texture and moderate carbonation. Great head retention, some lacing left on the glass. I really enjoyed this one.

Bottle.  Bright amber in colour.  Standard Three Floyd aroma - lots of hops -  pine and citrus.  The flavour was a bit milder then that aroma let on but still lots of citrus (grapefruit and pine) with only some light caramel malt near the back.  Bitter mouthfeel, medium body, medium-high carbonation.  Finishes with a lingering slightly dry bitterness.

Deeper amber color, tan head. Full aroma, very citrusy and piney hops, some malty sweetness. Flavor leans on the hops a bit too much, pretty bitter, not enough malt to back it up. Medium to full body, a touch dry. Pretty nice beer though.
Aroma of citrus and pine, copper, small toffee head. Flavour is a milder hoppiness then the nose, malt is nicely done here. Well balanced, medium bodied. A great session ale, I think.

Dark mahogany w/ beige finger of foam. Fresh, dewy, piny, woody hop aroma. Medium, moderately resiny feel. Flavour is surprisingly malty (caramel, toffee) & balanced w/ a piny, orange-y hop character.
bottle. thick resiny hop aroma. red brownish tinge. flavour also consists of generous hops but it doesnt come without pretty good balance. I enjoyed it.
More hophead feed. Grapefruit, floral aroma in hops.Mid-sip toast. Medium mouthfeel. Not the best Three Floyd.Radekfest #2.

Quite pretty glowing red in the glass.  Its from Three Floyds so you know what the nose is - hops hops hops.  The nose also has some brown sugar and tea.  This isnt as hoppy as the nose suggests, rich malt, fruity with more of that lemon/orange tea.  Some caramel in the finish.  The carbonation level is great.
UPDATED: MAY 19, 2006 Light amber color with a small beige head. Piney hop aroma.  Creamy body. Flavor of hops, citrus  and some caramel malt.

Deep ruby red brown liquid with a nice head of foam leaving a good lace.  Nose is sharply hoppy with a hint of evergreen.  Dry hops with a very mild malt body.  Clean and crisp.  Clean finish.  Pleasant slightly pine flavored aftertaste.

Bottle.  Oh Billy, Billy, Billy... Oops, wrong Baru. Bright copper to burnt orange in color with a dissipating beige head that leave a large ring of lace on the top and smaller speckle the rest of the way down the glass. Sweet grapefruit aromas, the sweetness well brought out by the malt. Certainly a hopshead amber nose. But not too overdone. There are some floral and malt scents as well. Fairly thick for an amber, or irish red, but more what I would expect from FFF, so all is well.  Flavors start with a pale malt sweetness with a mild toastiness. Hops come in to balance things out with mild pine and citrus. Balances well, but seems to thin out in flavor the further down the glass I go. Linger is quite dry with just a hint of husky grain. Actually quite an easy and enjoyable quaff.

This was my first 3 Floyds and it was pretty cool.  Dark amber in color with very little white thin head.  hoppy, bitter, with some malt, carmel, and pine flavors.  makes for an intriguing taste more than anything.

This had a reddish brown appearance. A definite pine and orange peel presence in the flavor which is not something you would expect in this style. A good balance of hop bitterness and malt presence. It has the 3 Floyds taste if you know what I mean, which isnt a bad thing. Interesting session ale.

Huge thanks to BBB63 for sharing this. Pours a beautiful dark red color, similar to cherry juice,  small tan head, not a lot of carbonation. Aroma is full of sweet caramel with pine and citrus notes as well. Flavor is  sweet, with a hoppy body to it. Lots of pine and grapefruit comes through. Malt/caramel sweetness rounds out the flavor. Thanks to BBB63 for sharing this one.

A very hoopy and fruity aroma.  The moderate heads has a little staying power, but theres plenty of lacing on my glass, from the bottled beer.  Its hoppy, but I expect that from the makers of Alpha King.  It starts sweet, but it just didnt do it for me.  The hops produce a harsh aftertaste I just dont appreciate.

Tap.  Damn, another reason not to dislike Amber Ales.  Caramel copper colored.  Nice off-white head.  Sweet and fruity aroma.  At times this beast smells like Juicy Fruit gum.  Initial sweetness is offset quickly by the Floyds judicious use of hops.  Very piney at times.  A well done Amber!

Bottle. Pours a ruby tinged copper. Medium foamy tanned head. Nose is very hoppy and piney. Not what I was expecting for an Irish Red Ale, although, were I to simply smell this, I think I could "pick out" Three Floyds. Taste is hoppy and piney but has a nice malty character to it and even some light hints of caramel despite how dominant the hop profile is. Body is medium with moderate carbonation and light lingering bitterness. Finish produces a reduced hop profile, some earthy notes, light caramel and some pleasant sweet maltiness. I want to say that there is some pumpernickel bread notes in here was well. Or is it poorly made rye bread (not a knock on 3F). Different and just what I was looking to drink after work!

Interesting taste here, felt like I was drinking a combination of a red ale and an IPA. The amount of hops in this definitely puts a spin on the style. Overall I enjoyed it, but it probably wont be a regular purchase.

Clear copper body topped by a rocky manila head. Decent glass lace. The aroma is strong and hits you the second the cap is popped. And that aroma, contrary to what you might expect with a beer labeled Irish Red Ale, is loads of pine and citrus hops. There arent this many hops in all of Ireland, unless of course they replaced the potatoes with hops and that is why they had that famine. Anyhow... The flavor is not as nice as the aroma caramel and light bread trying to come through but like a street urchin in the hands of a drunk Irish cop the malt is being bashed into oblivion by the heavy hand of sire OHoppolly. Bitter throughout. Medium smooth palate. Decent enough and a liberal take on the style (call it Irish Red or Amber Ale).

Intersting to say the least but for some reason it just didnt do it for me. First off the nose is hot. Lots of hops but not overly agressive. The taste has this hops in it and thats all good but there is this strange flavour that is supposed to be amber but to me it just doesnt do it. The others that had this with me absolutely loved it tho, so maybe its just me. Overall, not that bad and its from three floyds so you gotta give it a shot.

Bought this on a whim.  Very glad.  Pours a tawny amber with more significant brown leanings than anything else.  The aroma is sticky pine, and tangerine citrus hops.  Spicy, floral, and crisp.  The flavor consists of great malts.  Lite sweetness where you can detect caramel, grain (biscuit?), and wood.  Mineral.  Well hoped but balanced with hop flavors including a start of grapefruit and orange, which moves to a spicy finish of hoppiness.  The body is a bit more watery than I suspected but clean and solid.  Im not usually a big fan of red ale but Id drink this all the time.  Hello beer fridge!!!!

very hoppy smell with some citrus hints.  taste is of pine and fruit with hops.. i agree with a few posts down.. this is just a slight change on the other three floyds brews.  nothing super spectacular but it was good and now i have the bottle for my collection.

Fridge Temp. A serious true red in a English pint. Smells just like a pack of hops pellets. Awesome. Flavor is more expansive hoppiness, not overwhelming or too much citrus. I am not getting the grapefruit everyone is describing, this seems much more piney and herbal to me than west coast hop monsters. Brilliant, eminently drinkable, I wish the was always in every beerstore in America. I need cases of this!!!

UPDATED: APR 11, 2005 I dont know what to say about this one except that this aint no Irish Ale, its a red IPA or amber ale.  Lets see now, 3F have made a west coast IPA(Alpha King) and Imperial IPA(Dreadnaught), a black IPA(last years Alpha Klaus), a Barleywine IPA(Behemoth), a Imperial Stout IPA(Dark Lord), a white IPA Gumballhead Wheat and now a Red IPA(Brian Boru).  First Ill say Ive enjoyed all of them, and with this one priced at between 5-6 a bottle I really apprecaited this one.  I havent had all their beers but the ones Ive had are getting repetitive.

A lovely looking beer, the color of which seems more than appropriate for St. Pats.  Nose doesnt match up.  Malty, but somewhat thin (unusual for FFF).  Flavor is crisp, refreshin, and full of malt, citrus, and other flavors.  As easy drinking beer and DEFINITELY a top notch amber.  For a style that is often ho-hum at best, this brew has reinvigorated my interest.

Well, if youre looking for the typical St. Patricks day Irish style red ale.....this aint it!  And coming from 3 Floyds, would you expect it any other way?  Nice citrus hop aroma - Id guess Amarillo and it says so on the bottle.   But its also piney and flowery along with the grapefruit.  Taste is sweet smokey malt up front turning exceptionally hoppy the last 3/4 of the sip.   Body is medium - not too thick - you could drink a lot of this.  Im not a big fan of Amber Ales anyway, so Ive gotta give them credit for giving this one some kick

Wow, hoppy as hell smell; the odor attacked me when I opened the bottle.  Deep pretty red color.  Thin,weak head that barely lasted, thin mouth feel.  Heavy Hop taste.  I will be buying another bottle to share with friends.

Leave it to Three Floyds to break the mold on a straightforward and common beer style. This beer is a dark clear reddish-amber color with a tall and foamy beige head. Thin patches of lacing throughout the glass. The aroma is amazingly floral, with hops and malt in the wings. Medium-bodied and very hoppy, with some citrus, malt and caramel flavors. The finish is bitter and hoppy yet somewhat smooth. Stacked up against the rest of the Amber Ales out there, this one definitely raises eyebrows.

Yeah, somewhere in here the malt is saying "Let me up, I want to shine - Im supposed to be an Irish Ale". Grab a Conways or several other examples, as the malt presence here is of the right type but muted by, as in all 3F products, huge, high alpha acid PNWish hops. Piney, grapefruity, and not a lot more, except for the little earthy cry by the malt addition that longs to be heard. Boring and watery and thin, but above average. Maybe.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text:
UPDATED: MAY 5, 2005 I dont know what kind of crack I was on the first time I had this but my first review was just silly. Not hardly bitter at all, in fact very smooth. Still quite hoppy though in that lovely American way. I got a totally different impression this time through, oddly enough, the numbers are unchanged. Ha!

Original rating: Irish red my ass. This shit is hoppy as fuck and incredibly, parchingly bitter. Nice red color with loads of lace. Medium body dried out by a healthy dose of hops. Not at all balanced but tasty as hell.
Smell is fruity-hoppy. Reminiscent of Alpha King, but much more mellow. A very light hop flavor with a robust malt backbone. Excellent sticky lacing.
Bottle poured a dark reddish-brown color with a heavy aroma of piney hops. Medium-sized, mostly lasting head. Light fruitiness in the flavor with a bitter hop finish.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2005 Floral aroma with an interesting hop quality for an amber ale.  Sweet and smooth malts prevail throughout but Its well crafted and balanced.  Thick head on a red body.  Good stuff.

Wow, what a nice beer.  I really have never had even a mediocre Floyds beer.  Yes, its hoppy-big surprise!  But still a lovely malt backbone and its damn tasty my friend.  I wish new Floyd beers came around more often.
Draught.  Appears dark ruby in low light.  Solid red/ amber.  Clean, fresh taste with notes of caramel.  Hop presence is there, but understated.  Solid ale.

Copper, red tint appearance.  Nice fluffy white head.  Standard FFF beer.  Good crisp malts up front, and a mellow hop presence in the back.  More of a session beer lacking the normal high hop content of the usual FFF beer.

Fresh Bottle. Suitably red, with a nice stable head. A big smell of fresh hops which I usually get with my 3Fs stuff and that Im told is from dry hopping. Lusty toasted malts keep this just above being called a session beer. Of course, theres a big hop aftertaste. Should be in six packs with the rest of their regular beers.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2005 From the 3F tap:  This big-headed Irish starts off with a fragrant, well hopped aroma that doesnt completely cover the rich, fruity malts.  Its good and malty as an Irish should be, though heavier on the fruity flavors than  the caramel.  The hops, for 3F, arent overwheming but give a good, solid, pine and citric balance of bitterness.  Finishes on a snappy, bitter note.  Good stuff.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Floyds Brewing Company, Munster, IN<font size=-1>
Over the top, highly hopped Irish Red that has a very creamy mouthfeel...surprisingly bitter base with a sweet  malty balance that I really enjoyed.  Fresh from the tap at the brewery.

The more 3F I try the more similar all there beers seem.  Upon first popping the top to the bomber I had to look twice as the aroma was exactly like Gumbalhead.  Pours amber with a large thick tan head.  Typical 3F amarillo hop aroma.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Oily hop, caramel taste.  A quality beer that I am finding the brewers hop profile to be one dimensional after tasting 7 of their beers, IMO.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2005 Re -rate, from bottle Brian is back for 05! The beer pours a reddish amber with a strong, floral, piney aroma. Strong, persistent, foamy head. Good, strong malty flavor with a bit of a carmelly aftertaste. The beer is not as bitter as you might expect from the aroma; the hops are mostly in the background, which is a nice change from FFFs normal stuff (not that Im complaining!)

I managed to have the last half pint at Bone Dry Bar (near FFF).  It was my first beer all year, ok, first "half beer".  Copper color with surprisingly fruity nose.  Malty first sip was caramelly and rich, I had almost forgotten what beer tasted like.  Finish was pure FFF heaven, plenty of lingering strong hops and an aftertaste that stayed hoppy for an hour.  This could lead me straight down the path to beergeek again in no time,  Thanks Nick... maybe Ill go back up to XXl in shirt size...

On tap, Bone Dry, Highland, IN. A lot more going on than you would think in a red. Medium-full body, white head, deep red coloring. Very floral up front and in the nose. Smooth in the middle diminshing dry at the end. Quite surprising and quite drinkable.

Pours a reddish copper with an off-white head.  Very hoppy aroma with citrus tones.  Creamy mouthfeel. Sweet, caramel, toffee flavor. A very good brew.  This was from a growler shared by "jables" from his keg.  Many thanks.

Aroma:  very sweet, kiwi fruit scents and pine with a small musty aroma

Appearance:  dark brown with a small head

Flavor:  kiwi fruits, pine, bubble gum, and slight musty flavor.  loaded with hops, very fruity--small hoppy/piney aftertaste.  a very drinkable beer

Palate:  dry, bitterness at the back of the tongue and roof of the mouth.  very flavorful.  carbonation just perfect.

Overall:  a very enjoyable beer

Sampled at the brewery.  Very sweet pineapple, kiwi, and sweet lime hopped aroma.  Good caramel malty flavors, overall very hopped, as usual from FFF.  Lingering hop finish of sweet pineapple and kiwi fruit.  A mellow beer, the hops arent as punch-you-in-the-face as other offerings.  Sweet bubblebum flavor.  Color is a deep brown with a tan head, slightly cloudy.  Very drinkable.

I was with three other people and they all agreed that this was a very good beer.It was thick with caramel amber body.It has a  good hopped aroma. There were citrus elements.With a smooth and creamy mouthfeel.
UPDATED: MAR 20, 2004 On tap at the brewery (and at home, ha,ha,ha). Tons of hop character for a red ale. Piney and grapefruity aroma. Very good. Not a typical red ale, but a red pale ale.

Draft at the brewery.  Murky brown with a thin head.  The nose was so pungent with hops that it reminded me of b.o.  I must have got all the grain astringency out of hey_kevin's sample.  Very hoppy for an amber with lots of celery greens.  This beer seemed one dimensional to me, and it wasn't the amber/red dimension.
This reddish color beer had a smoky scent, which was evident in the taste as well. Very smooth.

A treat when arriving to pick u the long awaited Dark Lord. Sweet pine fragrance, medium mouthfeel, crisp, less hoppy hen most of the other FFF brews, and beautiful auburn color. Nick can't find enoguh time to make more of these gemstoo bad. Great Irish red ale.

Deep amber.  Huge intense amarillo hop aroma, mangoes and apricots.  As always with 3F, excellent hop flavor.  Not out of balance toward bitterness either.  Pleasant caramel malt character, without a trace of roasty astringency.  A good example of what I consider a non-style (irish ale) made interesting, bravo!

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2005 Thick, caramel amber body with a full, fluffy white head.  Heavily hopped aroma with strong citrus elements and a underlying pine.  Also elements of caramel and toffee deep underneath.  Smooth and creamy mouthfeel, this doesnt feel as thick as it really is.  Sweet, sticky caramel and toffee malt lays at the base while strong hoppy grapefruit, orange and pine resin come through.  Another hoppy beer from Three Floyds, however, I think they always mix it up enough to make it interesting.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2005 this is a smooooth and sweet ale. piney, orange, aftertaste. cremey palate. mostly hops, alas, but ya know. hadnt i shared my growler id give you a better review, however, it doesnt matter just know that its good. UPDATE 4/24/05 & 4/25/05: this is different than i remember. spicy, citrus/orange, floral hops. toffee, sweet malts. a little earthy. a little watery palate, but the mouthfeel is lively, and paradoxically slightly cremey... as if to balance it out in an old Irish way? Meh... anyway... it is smooth, and delicious. personally, a strong and wonderful session brew!

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2005 It was like a lopsided battle, like none ever seen before. On one side was a host of purported Irish paragons; Killians, Caffreys, & Finnegans. Standing alone, wind whipping through his hair, was Brian Boru. He was brashly-hoppily American, yet grounded as only a grounded malty Irishman could be. A legendary warrior with a holy hop scepter rumored to be blessed by the American Hop-Goddess herself.

Unexpectedly Boru sprung forth at his red Irish opponents. He was bitter, where they were mellow. He had a backbone strengthened by pure malt, where they were barely supported by misappropriated adjuncts. Borus scepter swept forth like a clean lemon acidity separating & curdling milk. They fled before Boru, the beast that was suckled at the teat of the hop nectar goddess.

Before friends Boru was sweet, but, quiver all ye foes for he shall unleash his bitter wrath upon all who displease him.

The women loved him, for when he passed lusty remembrances of rolling in the hay, with scents of pine needles, citrus, roses, and fruit waft through their minds.

In the end it is the unique dichotomy between the Irish & American that makes Boru so likeable, hoppily brash, yet smoothly malty, what is not to like.

So far only availible at the brewery, go out and get some if you have the chance.

Growler from Munster: creamy red caramel poured from the jug, offering a large orange/brown waterfall of bubbles.  Characteristic Three Floyds piney aroma, but with more sugary sweetness.  Also reminded me of orange and grapefruit penny candy. . .creamy palate, with toasted pine cones, tangy grapefruit and orange zest.  Not as bitter as Dreadnaught or AK, but plenty of hop flavour.  I noticed the malt more as my glass warmed: wheaty bread and toasted rye.  After thoughts of gooey caramel and a bit of vanilla.  I wonderfully drinkable beer for me.
Draft at brewery. Bit of a murky brown red body with an off-white head. Very VERY piney aroma. It may as well be a pine tree. Tastes has... piney hops with some orange citrus in it.

My mouth still tasted like the Warrior hops in this bad boy,this morining. Murky,brown-first glass had specks. Green,sappy,hop aroma. I just couldn't smell any malt,very hoppy. Creamy,well carbonated,medium body. Some malt(toasty,bready),with tons of grapfruit. Finish is resiny,sappy. Very drinkable, though,hopped all to hell. I had a few!

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2005 Small biscuity malt with spruce and orange citrus hops.  This rating isnt very descriptive, but the beer was enjoyable to drink.  It reminded me of a malty APA featuring sprucy hops.

Re-rate 5/23/05.  Bottle.  Clear but dark brown-red body.  Nutmeg/coriander spicy spruce hop aroma with a brownie, deep caramel and butterscot candy malt backing.  Wonderful aroma!  The flavor is a bit of a letdown after the tempting aroma.  The same hops are there but the malt backbone isnt on the same level as in the aroma.  Bitter hops and a bit of dry peat in the finish.

On tap: Muddy brownish red with off-white head and good lace. Nice piney and juicy nose with additional hints of caramel, nutty, celery, light spice and earthy yeast esters. The taste starts bitter and buttery. A spicy and toasted malt midsection. The finish was slightly chalky and hinted of grapefruit. Lively and refreshing mouthfeel, smooth. A solid amber to celebrate the upcoming St. Patrick day. Recommended.
